page.title: 18ECOLOGY IN THE WEDMORE AREA
page.content: Dutch Elm Disease has changed the appearance of the lowlands as elms were very common and have not been replaced. Willow trees are pollarded for use in basket weaving. Many farmers spray their hayfields and this prevents wild flowers from growing. The hedgerows are a good source of plant life, in June we found 40 different species of wild flower. Birds of special interest include heron, kingfisher, woodpeckers, owls and a pair of hobbies nesting in a disused crow's nest. Rabbits are the most common mammal. There are a great variety of small mammals, with several species of mice. Many different bats can also be found. At least 200 foxes inhabit the area and 50 badgers, in 4 or 5 groups. Footpaths are plentiful but very few are used regularly.
